image.altText: People dressed in white, all-body suits at the entrance to a building.

props.synopsis: The ACT has closed 69 schools over the coloured sand asbestos scare. Why is it the only jurisdiction to do so?

title.children: Why is the ACT the only jurisdiction to close schools over coloured sand?

image.altText: A building with a blue sign that reads: Evatt Primary School.

props.synopsis: The ACT will close more schools after additional coloured sand products were recalled by Kmart and Target, while the schools that were shut on Friday will reopen on Monday.

title.children: ACT to close 69 schools after extra coloured sand products recalled

image.altText: Two people wearing full-body and head white anti-contamination suits leave a building carrying bags of coloured matter.

props.synopsis: Seventeen schools were shut down on Friday after concerns about asbestos exposure. The reopening of one of the schools has been fast-tracked.

title.children: 'If it was my child': Epidemiologist not worried by asbestos in sand

image.altText: Kungka Kunp (Strong Women) at the Rock (2023) by Kaylene Whiskey.

props.synopsis: Dolly Parton has never stepped foot on the dry red dirt of Indulkana in remote South Australia, but she is a frequent visitor in the art of Kaylene Whiskey, which celebrates sisterhood and strong women.

title.children: 'No one like her in the universe': Meet rising art star Kaylene Whiskey

image.altText: A woman plays with her son using blocks.

props.synopsis: A recall of children’s coloured sand after asbestos traces were found has led to the closure of multiple public schools in the ACT, leaving parents scrambling for care options and answers.

title.children: 'Chaos situation' as asbestos risk in coloured sand causes school closures

image.altText: Kadink Sand

props.synopsis: Schools in Canberra and Brisbane are closed today due to asbestos in decorative coloured sand.

title.children: Asbestos found in coloured play sand, prompting school closures

image.altText: Three tower waterslides, all in a significant state of disrepair.

props.synopsis: Canberra's only water park will remain shut for the summer despite promises by the site's owners it would reopen by mid-November.

title.children: Big Splash confirms at 'eleventh hour' that water park will remain shut

image.altText: Sussan Ley

props.synopsis: Sussan Ley says she is not worried her leadership is on the rocks after a bumpy week for the opposition. Follow live.

title.children: Moderates rally behind Ley's leadership as Albanese labels Liberal energy policy 'nonsensical'

image.altText: A bald man wearing a grey outfit stands in a field near some buildings.

props.synopsis: After Palestinians were expelled from three refugee camps in the Israeli occupied West Bank this year, some fear a new ceasefire in Gaza could prompt Israel to expand its operations in the area once more.

title.children: If this Palestinian returned home, he would be 'shot and killed'

image.altText: A power station looms over trees and a curved road, emitting vapour.

props.synopsis: Amid swirling debate among conservative politicians over decarbonisation, energy bosses have warned against turning away from net zero despite cost pressures.

title.children: Energy CEOs say 'no turning back' on renewables transition

image.altText: Woman in foreground and man looking towards her.

props.synopsis: The strange macho appeal of fossilised vegetation means that 30 years of annual United Nations meetings to stop the planet heating any more have been a bust.

title.children: Liberals aren't alone as net zero sceptics — but the data doesn't lie

image.altText: A photo of abstract artwork blue poles, which is made up of drips of red, yellow, white and black paint

props.synopsis: Art can stir strong feelings in people, both good and bad. These artworks fell in the latter, provoking great controversy in Australia, and telling us a lot about who we are as a nation.

title.children: These six artworks caused huge controversy in Australia

image.altText: A young woman wearing a pink jacket takes a selfie photo while clutching a notepad with text on it.

props.synopsis: Family and former colleagues of a Ukrainian journalist who was captured by Russian forces and tortured are determined to do everything they can to ensure those who contributed to her death are held responsible.

title.children: 'They were trying to erase her': Family seek justice for tortured journalist

image.altText: Tony Abbott stares into the distance.

props.synopsis: In 2011, Tony Abbott was questioned over his use of the phrase "shit happens" when discussing the death of an Australian soldier in Afghanistan. Instead of responding, he stared at the journalist, fighting the urge to thump him.

title.children: Tony Abbott reveals reason behind silence in 2011 stare-off with journalist

image.altText: cross section of a branch showing galleries bored by the beetle

props.synopsis: Growers in this major food bowl are nervous for their future, as the state focuses its shot-hole borer efforts on outer-Perth.

title.children: Nervous fruit growers brace for invasive beetle's impact

image.altText: man on stretcher with face obscured alongside helicopter ambulance

props.synopsis: Two men are in hospital with serious injuries after an alleged road-rage incident near Forster on the NSW Mid North Coast. A teenager travelling with the men was also injured when he tried to help.

title.children: Two in hospital after allegedly being run over in road-rage incident

image.altText: A young First Nations man sits on concrete stairs looking serious. He wears a dark hoodie.

props.synopsis: Nye was getting into trouble and making bad choices when he was handed a lifeline that helped him turn things around.

title.children: These young men escaped restless boredom that led to chaos and crime

image.altText: Michael Hutchence sits on a chair, leaning forward, with the rest of INXS behind him.

props.synopsis: The Velvet Revolution, an Australian rock star's legacy and the youngest ever Saturday Night Live host — do you recognise these events from Novembers past?

title.children: How well do you know this week in history?

image.altText: A selfie Emma Dickeson has taken of herself wearing activewear posing on a elevated waking path.

props.synopsis: Emma Dickeson says her "school night" adventures are about devoting time and attention to the things that energise you.

title.children: Avoiding 'just living for the weekend' is trending. Is it all it's cracked up to be?

image.altText: A blonde woman talks while wearing a red MAGA baseball cap.

props.synopsis: Once considered one of Donald Trump's most loyal soldiers, Marjorie Taylor Greene has found herself an outcast of the MAGA firm.

title.children: How Epstein drove a wedge between Trump and one of his most hardline advocates

image.altText: A stock trader looks down at a tablet as he works on the floor of a busy stock exchange while surrounded by screens.

props.synopsis: Wall Street has ended a volatile session with mixed results, while the ASX slide is expected to continue today. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Wall Street ends mixed and ASX set to slip further

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: SQM says it will defend ASIC legal action
BHP High Court defeat costs contained: RBC
ASX clawing back losses after early sell-off

image.altText: Gloved hands use tweezers to examine pink coloured sand in a zip-lock bag.

props.synopsis: Concerned families and retailers are inundating a materials testing laboratory with enquiries, since news broke that asbestos had been detected in decorative and coloured sand for children.

title.children: Families flock to hazard testing lab amid asbestos sand concerns

image.altText: a pothole in the middle of a road

props.synopsis: Across the country, labs conduct crucial testing on construction materials used for roads infrastructure projects. But not all are doing it properly, according to audit documents obtained exclusively by the ABC.

title.children: Secret surveillance reveals lab was suspected of shonky road test results

image.altText: Animation design of desalination plan

props.synopsis: Completion of the South Australian government’s Northern Water desalination plant and water pipeline is now forecast to occur in 2032.

title.children: $5b SA desal plant and pipeline network expected to take longer to finish

image.altText: A table of machetes

props.synopsis: Police have confiscated more than 15,000 bladed weapons this year amid heightened community concern over knife crime.

title.children: Victorian police seize record number of knives

image.altText: Protesters are sprayed in Mexico City as they try and pull down a barrier.

props.synopsis: The demonstration was mostly peaceful but ended with some young people clashing with the police.

title.children: Thousands protest in Mexico City as gen Z protests gain momentum

image.altText: Troy takes his jersey off, screams, runs, other teammates around in green shorts, white tee, climbing on each other in stadium.

props.synopsis: Ireland keeps its hopes alive of making the World Cup finals for the first time since 2002 with a stunning comeback.

title.children: Dublin erupts as late goal keeps Ireland's World Cup hopes alive

image.altText: A dark-haired man in a suit speaks at a lectern in front of an "AFL draft" backdrop.

props.synopsis: Another AFL draft has arrived, offering dozens of teenage footballers the chance to realise their dreams. Here is everything you need to know.

title.children: When is the AFL draft and how does it work? Here's what you need to know

image.altText: Woman in a wheelchair interviews man on red carpet at awards show. A camera films them in the foreground.

props.synopsis: The ABC is featuring stories by and about people with disability leading up to and following December 3, the International Day of People with Disability.

title.children: Australians tell their stories for International Day of People with Disability

image.altText: A man holds a Southern rock lobster

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian government closed two zones within the state's rock lobster fishery just hours after the commercial season opened. The closure is in response to concerns about an antibiotic being used by salmon companies and the rock lobster industry's reputation in overseas markets.

title.children: Salmon antibiotic leads to partial rock lobster fishery closure

image.altText: A sign that reads backed by Bedford.

props.synopsis: The federal health minister says the jobs of "hundreds and hundreds of South Australians who live with a disability" have been secured, as The Disability Trust is named as the preferred buyer to take over Bedford's supported employment and learning and experience programs.

title.children: Preferred buyer for Bedford says it will 'protect what matters the most'

image.altText: Ben Stokes yawns

props.synopsis: Has England compromised its pre-Ashes preparation by playing only one three-day warm-up match against its own reserve team before the first Test in Perth? The numbers say no.

title.children: England's 'arrogant' approach to its pre-Ashes warm-up may be immaterial

image.altText: Smiling Jannik Sinner holds a trophy in front of fireworks.

props.synopsis: Jannik Sinner has defeated world number one Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (4), 7-5 in the ATP Finals title decider, defending his crown.

title.children: Sinner beats Alcaraz to defend ATP Finals crown

image.altText: Kris Boyd looks to one side

props.synopsis: New York Jets cornerback Kris Boyd has been critically injured in a shooting in mid-town Manhattan.

title.children: NFL player in critical condition after being shot in New York

image.altText: MHIT thumbnail

props.synopsis: An officer who headed the NSW Police unit training the force in mental health responses once committed misconduct in a case where a mentally ill man was fatally shot by police.

title.children: A mentally ill man was shot dead by police. An officer involved was promoted
